Lead Story

Ouija Board Rules 7–2 Against Griswold Group in Landmark Hallway Carpet Dispute

By Agnes Periwinkle • Chief Correspondent • Feb 11, 2026

In what legal scholars are calling "unprecedented" and what I am calling "about damn time," the Spectral Arbitration Board ruled 7–2 Tuesday evening that the Griswold Group must replace the hallway carpet in Buildings 4 through 11 with material "not actively hostile to bare feet."

The planchette moved decisively to "YES" when asked if the current carpet ‚Äî a petroleum-based weave installed in 1987 and never cleaned ‚Äî constituted a habitability violation. Two dissenting spirits, identified via cold spot analysis as "Gerald" and "possibly a dog," abstained by spinning the planchette in circles for eleven minutes.

"The carpet has achieved sentience. It bit my nephew. The Ouija board understands what the municipal courts refuse to acknowledge."

‚Äî Agnes Periwinkle, at the post-session press conference she held in her kitchen

Griswold Group spokesperson Dana Whitfield-Cho released a statement calling the ruling "legally nonbinding, spiritually questionable, and frankly, an insult to carpet." She added that the company "does not recognize the jurisdiction of the deceased."

The Gazette has obtained internal Griswold emails showing the carpet's original purchase price: $0.47 per square yard, procured from a warehouse fire liquidation in Secaucus, New Jersey. At current replacement rates, updating all eight buildings would cost an estimated $34,200 ‚Äî or, as Chairman Meow noted in his official response, "four months of the CEO's parking stipend."

The ruling is the 14th consecutive Ouija verdict against Griswold this fiscal year. The company has complied with zero of them, citing a legal framework that "does not include ghosts." Agnes has filed a formal appeal with the spirit of Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who has not yet responded but did reportedly flicker the hallway lights twice.

Governance

Mascot Containment Protocol Fails for 847th Consecutive Day; Board Votes to Stop Trying

By Reggie Okafor-Blunt • Mascot Beat

The Tenant Council voted 9–1 Thursday to formally abandon the Mascot Containment Protocol, a $14,000 initiative that has failed to contain a single mascot since its inception in 2023. Chairman Meow, the sentient dust bunny who serves as the building complex's de facto spiritual leader, was seen entering the ventilation system during the vote itself, trailing what witnesses described as "pamphlets."

"We built the barriers. We installed the motion sensors. We hired a consultant named Phil," said Council Chair Loretta Vines, 54. "Phil quit. The sensors detect Chairman Meow but Chairman Meow does not detect the sensors. He is beyond containment."

At least six other mascots now roam freely across the complex, including "Deputy Whiskers" (a sock puppet believed to be autonomous), "The Honorable Fluffington III" (origin unknown, possibly summoned), and "Greg" (a regular pigeon that Chairman Meow has appointed Minister of Exterior Affairs).

The lone dissenting vote came from Apartment 4F's Harold Beem, 71, who insisted that "if we simply close the lobby doors, all of this stops." Harold's apartment was later found to contain 14 unauthorized mascots. He declined to comment.

Infrastructure

Elevator in Building 6 Now Only Goes to Floors That "Deserve It," Per Chairman Meow Directive

By Agnes Periwinkle • Feb 10, 2026

Residents of Building 6 reported Monday that the elevator has begun skipping the 3rd and 7th floors entirely, displaying a handwritten note taped to the panel reading "THESE FLOORS VOTED AGAINST THE RENT STRIKE. CONSEQUENCES." The note is signed with a paw print.

Griswold Group maintenance has confirmed the elevator is "mechanically fine" and that the floor-skipping is "not something an elevator should be able to do." Chairman Meow has not claimed responsibility but was seen exiting the elevator shaft at 2:47 AM carrying a small wrench.

Investigation

EXCLUSIVE: Griswold Group Paid $400 to Rig 2017 Shuffleboard Tournament, Documents Show

By Agnes Periwinkle • Investigative Desk

The Gazette has obtained receipts ‚Äî actual receipts, Brenda, printed on thermal paper ‚Äî proving that Griswold Group COO Martin Griswold Jr. paid recreational coordinator Steve Loomis exactly $400 in Applebee's gift cards to "adjust the tournament bracket" at the 2017 Summer Social Shuffleboard Championship.

I lost that tournament by two points. Two points, and a $25 gift certificate to Bath & Body Works. My chamomile collection would have been complete.

Loomis, reached by phone, said "I don't remember that" and then "please stop calling this number." He has now said "please stop calling this number" forty-one times across seventeen phone calls. The Gazette interprets this as a soft confirmation.

The implications are staggering. If Griswold rigged shuffleboard, what else did they rig? The 2019 potluck voting? The community garden plot lottery? The "random" fire alarm at 3 AM on the night of the condo board election? We will follow this story until the truth is known or I am physically removed from the premises, whichever comes first.
